and education business. And through that, one of the people coming through one of my classes actually was being recruited by 3COM, did not want to leave civil service, gave the recruiter my name and long story short, I ended up getting a job, getting an early out of the Air Force to join 3COM where I spent about two and a half years as a post-cells implementation engineer predominantly doing ATM networking, which was ahead of its time, I think, and then left there in 1999 to join Cisco as a systems engineer and spent four and a half years doing that role with Cisco moved into a leadership role back in 2004 timeframe and have been on the upward progression since then to the role I have now, which again is the SE Director for our sled business. Can you briefly explain what the difference between a post-cells engineer is and a pre-cells engineer making that transition from three-com to Cisco? When I joined three-com, I guess because my entire career had been from a military standpoint, operational, if you will, meaning that, you know, our job was to implement circuits. We were the knob-turners, if you will. And so we were the ones that really knew how to get this stuff to work, how to implement it, all those type things. When I talk about post-cells, it really is what I call

after the cell type approach. So you got the pre-cells engineers which are more, I'm not going to say we're not deep technologists, but it's more theoretical knowledge. We help customers with architecture, design. But we don't necessarily get too often into the bits and bytes of what is your IP, addressing scheme look like and where do you plug things exactly and, you know, where this switch sits and where that's what sits. So really your pre-cells job is to do architecture, design, bills and materials, stand up in front of an audience prior to the cell and make sure that they understand what they're getting, why they're buying what they buy. The post-cells team are the ones who take that pre-cells knowledge and actually turn it into a reality by doing the day-to-day for work which is the implementation and ongoing operational support. And so typically your post-cells engineers have a lot more what I call working knowledge of the systems and you have typically a lot

more innate troubleshooting skills because you spend most of your time trying to get things implemented and turned up and naturally through that process you're figuring out things that are breaking and not working right and how to get them going. No, perfect. it's streamlined if you will and it makes implementation faster it takes a lot of the you know and I'll say this to kind of interrupt myself as a lot of us as engineers were initially concerned well is this going to displace me or take my job actually it's the exact opposite you know I heard one of our former executives really well he said look I think the thing that we don't need to do is over rotate we've got a lot of people call CCIE CCNP CCNAs that have been quote-unquote programming network devices for years they've just been using command line the way they do that is going to change where we're using python json different languages to script to effectively get the same result but it's going to automate a lot of that stuff so that you're not having to repeat those functions box by box you can do it to essentialize so we'll call a controller so one of the things that Cisco started a few years back is called DevNet if you want to

access it you simply go to developer.sisco.com and when you go on that website they give you an opportunity to join DevNet and it's got a lot of modules that you can kind of a self-paced thing you can go through that teaches you really you have to have zero coding knowledge and you can really learn a great deal about how to configure networks voice equipment those type things to get out of them a more customized approach to how they handle your business so with DevNet it becomes become really a big deal a big part of Cisco live and we've got quite the community built the intent was obviously to ramp up the skill set and the engineering community around network automation and development and that type thing and now we've started this as part of DevNet DevNet experience where we have local events around the country and you'll see those listed out there and those are actually live events where you can go get hands on with a trainer

understand this huge shift that we're living in right now that creates a massive opportunity for really exciting careers and jobs that are opening around network engineering systems engineering cybersecurity that is all happening as Mark mentioned with a lot of let's say day-to-day tasks will be automated but it doesn't mean that these jobs will be going away just your role and your what you do on a daily basis is going to be more around orchestration creating policies and being able to do more creative things so to speak and I think that's really exciting now I'm curious Mark what is what makes up the digital Cisco digital network architecture what's that main controller let's talk about that okay we call it the apik em application programmable interface controller dash enterprise management and tear I know you you're very familiar with what we've done with ACI over the last couple years and the apik controller and the data center is around orchestrating

the Nexus 9000 series of switches and a lot of things we've talked about today will as that's evolved obviously you need to do the same thing for the campus and the whan edge so apik em is our controller for that environment and we started out with really three key things eat what we call easy QOS which is a way to automate quality of service if you've ever done any configs for quality of service you know it can be quite tedious and time consuming and the bigger the network the tougher it gets will be able to automate that so to speak to make sure that all of the switches are set up appropriately to handle for example a high quality video call takes a huge burden off of the staff and let's you get quicker to what your real job is which is supporting the business function not deploying quality of service configurations the next thing is plug-in play and again this is if you can imagine what's very time consuming is switch by switch

configurations truck rolls all those type things so being able to deploy for example switches in a stat and have a policy and of configs built where that switch kind of phones home to the controller realized it's where it lives and then self configures if you will and inserts itself into a stack that again are the type things that we're working on and the last thing is around i-wan which is the our SD-WAN capability and being able to again all for a software to find WAN service it's easy to troubleshoot easy to deploy those type things so that's the initial three but as you can imagine with apkm offering you the ability to script around doing things one of the things you could imagine being possible going for is are things like audits typically you got to go switch by switch route or by router and pull those configs do some analysis on them so forth and so on around particular audits whether something the irs or some law enforcement requirement would have you do well

you can imagine now with apkm being able to develop a script that would effectively go out and even give an executive an easy button if you will to do a quick audit check on the environment and give you back a port so i think it's a fascinating time to be in the industry and as you look at you sysco and others opening up our platforms the ability to get creative around how you interact with the infrastructure and i think the last piece of this you didn't call out when you were talking about iot what people are really after is the data right because watch you have the data whether telemetry from our network components or telemetry data from sensors then your ability to act on that data and make better decisions to service your citizens or handle public safety those type things that's really where the magic happens today for most of us no i love it mark i mean there's a lot of takeaways here too that i would personally love for our listeners to start thinking

about looking at technology and better understanding how to tie solutions to actual business problems and that will create a lot of value for your team your organization like mark mentioned a bunch of things here like not only increasing your productivity with things like easy qs i remember doing auto qs back in my day and saved a lot of time doing voice projects and deploying network devices faster like if you need a top of rack switch right mark you don't want to be able to you want to be able to just plug and play that not spend three hours configuring that it's you know so you want to spend your energy spend your time doing more awesome creative work and getting these projects implemented sooner rather than later so what were some of the biggest lessons you've learned from getting your team to work on this this huge initiative or project if you will really good question Terry the i'll tell you the toughest thing right is um i've got engineers that

are like me and their mid fifties all the way to engineers in their mid-twenties and so what i would say is anytime you've got that diverse of a group with diverse skill sets i think the biggest lesson learned for me is where i would have assumed that my team members with the programming skills would have been the initial group to latch on and take this forward the interesting thing it ended up been uh one of my engineers which is no programming experience whatsoever but he does have his ccae and he i think what got him so interested is he found a customer opportunity where he could really make this a reality so timing is everything as we always hear and you said something interesting earlier that i think uh really to me has me continually enamored and passionate about the pre-sales role is we are constantly looking for ways and concert with our customers to help them figure out how to use Cisco technology with to solve a real-world business problem right and so i can't talk

about the specific customer but we have a customer that is one of our departments of transportation and we really lucked into this meaning that it was going to be a traditional network cell and the customer application development team got involved and when they realized that they could actually write fog applications directly to our industrial ethernet switches the game changed because all of a sudden now talking about iot one of the big things there is your ability to obviously with interstates and all these roads uh you can't transfer to all this actionable data back to a data center and then act on at any reasonable time with car driving 70 80 a hundred miles an hour right yep and so an example would be if you've got fog areas having having fog is catastrophic what you're talking about California or the deep south and you see these big pile ups and those type things will those obviously end up a lot of cases unfortunately with fatalities will think about

today's network if you had the ability to close interstate off ramps that would lead into areas where you could potentially have a safety hazard or you could trigger digital speed limit science to start throttling traffic that miles before a fog bound area you could see how those are real business challenges that dot would be trying to face and the fact that Cisco can get involved with those type situations and help a customer really resolve those those are the fun type things so think the big lesson learned here for us is that while this stuff looks like it's somewhat pie in the sky at time it is a it's a real world scenario that's playing out everywhere every day and i think the speed that we thought we would be able to travel if you will to get people ramped up and ready was far slower than the requirement that's really out there because this stuff's happening today we're seeing a lot of grants and things come around for what you're

talking about autonomous cars smart city initiatives all those type things that are really requiring  our scs to rethink how they go to market in this programmability part of our job has become a today  reality not something we had to focus on have a longer term time to focus on absolutely and  for those listening internet of things is driving a lot of innovation and demand different skill  sets and that's mark mention around industrial kind of market there is a new certification  from Cisco actually called the Cisco industrial networking specialist you could actually  certify in this and mark mentioned i.e. switches or the industrial ethernet rugged switch  and that provided a huge seems like solution for one of your big big customers yep sure was  and hopefully we can scale it out to even more but you know that's that's probably been the  biggest thing for us it's just the evolution of what an engineer has to be capable of today

as shifting very very quickly and so again a fun time to be in the industry absolutely now let's talk about some keys to success smart you've found a lot of success throughout your career and i'm curious what some daily or weekly rituals that have helped you become successful the first one terrier is just yet you really do have to be passionate about oh what you do right i run into people what they were talking about at Cisco with customers when i was three com or in the military that are they're just going through the motions so the first thing is and john chambers said this at one of our i think our 30th birthday event is just uh i never realized this about myself and about the people who've been the most successful but this intense curiosity around in our case technology and and what it can do for in our case here in sled you think about the way we go to market when i go talk to a principal or a superintendent i'm talking as a dad or a grandfather right so it's real world and the fun

thing about what we do for a living here uh in my organization is you have a real link to the customers you're visiting because you are their customer right so i just think that intense curiosity that keeps you driven for example i get up early every day anywhere from five to five thirty i try to spend even still today although i've been in management for years to spend at least an hour reading blogs reading different post research in the industry taking online training that we offer to Cisco some of those type things just to stay short on what we do so that's probably thing number one number two is what i just characterizes relentless work ethic i know it's easy to get caught up you know my son's 22 years also i can certainly relate to younger generations and you know i grew up on a farm so whether you wanted to work or you didn't you had to and so we grew up with that rise early you work all day you're relentless about what you do and i know times they've certainly changed but you know i think

what employers look at today and you can really see as employees who really have an invested interest in what they do and that plays out and in the way they show up and uh that the tenacity that they work uh every day i love it the third one i would just wrap it up with is balance right people asking me all the time will mark how do you work in the garden and spend time in the outdoors and work on your farm and still cover 27 states and lead to 137 people i think you got to keep things in perspective right because there's hopefully going to come a day when all of us retire and and lay back and you can't have uh burned the candle at both ends and only focused on work for your entire career and then wake up suddenly and and realize there's other parts of life so you just got to keep balance i know tear you worked with Cisco and it's a struggle at times but you just got to keep things in perspective and remember that family and hobbies and all those things
